summary: This is a 2007 New York Post article reporting that Jeffrey Epstein's lawyers are considering asking federal prosecutors to drop the requirement that he register as a sex offender as part of his plea deal. The article references a draft letter from Epstein's lawyer Gerald Lefcourt to U.S. Attorney Alexander Costa, and notes Epstein's connection to Daily News owner Mort Zuckerman.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the case who has agreed to plead guilty to soliciting underage prostitutes at his Palm Beach mansion in exchange for 18 months in prison. His lawyers are seeking to avoid sex offender registration.

persons.name: Gerald Lefcourt
persons.context: Epstein's lawyer who drafted a letter to U.S. Attorney Alexander Costa arguing against requiring Epstein to register as a sex offender.

persons.name: Alexander Costa
persons.context: The federal prosecutor to whom Epstein's lawyer Gerald Lefcourt drafted a letter regarding the sex offender registration requirement.

persons.name: Mort Zuckerman
persons.context: Identified as a former business partner of Jeffrey Epstein.

connections.description: Lefcourt is acting as Epstein's defense attorney, drafting legal arguments on his behalf regarding sex offender registration.
Lefcourt drafted a legal letter to federal prosecutor Costa regarding Epstein's case.

events.title: News report on potential plea deal modification
events.description: The New York Post reports that Jeffrey Epstein's lawyers are considering asking federal prosecutors to drop the requirement that he register as a sex offender as part of his plea agreement.

events.title: Epstein's guilty plea agreement
events.description: Epstein has agreed to plead guilty to state charges of soliciting underage prostitutes at his Palm Beach mansion in exchange for 18 months in prison and the federal investigation being dropped.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein had agreed to plead guilty to soliciting underage prostitutes at his Palm Beach mansion in exchange for an 18-month prison sentence.
Epstein's lawyers were considering asking federal prosecutors to drop the requirement that he register as a sex offender, arguing it would have a 'profound impact' on him.
The federal investigation into possible federal criminal violations was dropped as part of Epstein's plea deal with state prosecutors.
Epstein was a former business partner of Daily News owner Mort Zuckerman.
